page.title: 09FARMING(SHEEP)
page.content: Although the annual wool clip provides a source of some income, this is only secondary to the income derived from the sale of fat lambs. Consequently the selection of sheep breeds and management of flocks is geared to meat rather than wool production. The native breed of these uplands is the WELSH MOUNTAIN SHEEP, but in this area it has been modified by crossing with Cheviot rams to produce the BRECKNOCK HILL CHEVIOT, now recognised to be a separate breed. Further cross -ing with lowland breeds,notably the SUFFOLK, has greatly improved the size and weight of the lambs. Each farm has its resident flock of breeding ewes to which is added each years crop of ewe lambs.The ram lambs are sold for slaughter at about 6 months old. No wethers are kept as would be the case for wool.
